moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 f6: If I'm going to play the Italian Game, I need to learn what all these odds-and-ends defenses are.
moves.4. Nc3 Nge7 5. O-O g6 6. b3: Getting ready to fianchetto my bishop.
moves.6... d6 7. d4 Bg4: Smart move - pinning the knight and removing the defender from my pawn.
moves.8. d5 Nd4: A powerful outpost for his knight.
moves.9... c6 10. Nbxd4 exd4 11. Qxd4: I took with the queen rather than the knight in order to attack the f6 pawn.
moves.11... Ng8: Not sure why he did this... the better move would probably have been Bg7 to defend the f6 pawn. I understand the double-defense here, but underdeveloping a piece is not quite worth that.
moves.12. dxc6 bxc6 13. Bf4 c5 14. Bb5+: A nice sort of in-between move. Also making him lose his ability to castle.
moves.14... Kf7: A fairly bad blunder... Ke7 would probably have been the better move.
moves.15. Qd5+: Here's where the attack really takes off.
moves.15... Be6 16. Qb7+: At this point, I'm starting to press black's entire piece structure back toward the h8 corner.
moves.16... Ne7 17. Bxd6 Kg8: Probably trying to remove the pin on the knight, seeing that Qxd6 was not an option.
moves.18. Bc4 Qxd6: A mistake that cost him a rook.
moves.19. Qxa8 h5: Trying to give himself some room to move.
moves.20. Rad1 Qb6 21. Bxe6+: An exchange designed to press his pieces further yet into the corner of the board.
moves.22... Kh7 23. Rxf8: I exchange, and win a piece in the process.
moves.23... Rxf8 24. Qxf8 Ng8: Trying to prevent the queen from coming in and mating the king too quickly.
moves.25. g3: Planning to play Rd1 and subsequently Rd8, but in order to do this I would need something to prevent the back-rank mate by the black queen.
moves.25... g5: Again, giving his king room to move.
moves.26. Rd1 h4 27. Rd8 hxg3 28. fxg3: This was a major mistake on my part. hxg3 would have been a much stronger move.
moves.28... g4 29. Nh4 f5 30. exf5: Another mistake. I'm leaving my king too exposed here.
moves.30... Qe3+: The beginning of a series of checks in an attempt by black to set up a perpetual check and draw the game.
moves.31. Kf1 Qc1+ 32. Ke2 Qxc2+ 33. Ke3 Qc1+: Black did not find a solution from here. As soon as I could bring my king toward h8, it was an easy mate for me, and I could prevent the continuous check.
